titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Boris I. Bittker Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Barbara Heck and staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 07:16

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, legal pleadings, memoranda, newspaper clippings, reports, subject files, and writings that document Boris I. Bittker's career as a professor at Yale Law School from 1946 to 2006. In addition to voluminous materials relating to taxation, the papers also include correspondence and subject files relating to Bittker's book, Case for Black Reparations (1973), and a small amount of materials relating to his role in the prosecution of the case of Ex Parte Quirin as a lawyer in the Office of Lend-Lease Administration from 1942-1943. Accession 2014-A-060 contains course notes from Yale Law School, 1938-1941.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Daniel Bittker and Susan Bittker, 2006. Transferred from the Yale Law Library, 2013-2014.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by Daniel Bittker and Susan Bittker for materials Boris I. Bittker authored or otherwise produced. After the lifetimes of both Daniel Bittker and Susan Bittker, copyright passes to Yale University. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Boris I. Bittker Papers. (MS 1869). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Boris Irving Bittker was born on November 16, 1916, in Rochester, New York. He received his B.A. from Cornell University in 1938. Bittker attended Yale Law School and obtained his LL.B. in 1941. He clerked for Judge Jerome N. Frank on the U. S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

Bittker worked as an attorney in the Office of Emergency Management, Foreigh Economic Administration (Lend-Lease Administration) from 1942 until he was inducted into the Army. He served as an infantryman in Europe and was awarded a Purple Heart. In 1946, he returned to Yale Law School as an assistant professor and was thereafter promoted to the posts of Southmayd Professor (1951), Sterling Professor of Law (1970), and Professor Emeritus (1983). Bittker was a prolific author and renowed expert in taxation, as evidenced by his two most influential casebooks Federal Income, Estate, and Gift Taxation and Federal Income Taxation of Corporations and Shareholders.
Boris I. Bitter died on September 8, 2005, and was survived by his two children, Daniel Bittker and Susan Bittker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, legal pleadings, memoranda, newspaper clippings, reports, subject files, and writings that document Boris I. Bittker's career as a professor at Yale Law School from 1946 to 2006. In addition to voluminous materials relating to taxation, the papers also include correspondence and subject files relating to Bittker's book, Case for Black Reparations (1973) and a small amount of materials relating to his role in the the prosecution of the case of Ex Parte Quirin as a lawyer in the Office of Lend-Lease Administration from 1942-1943. Accession 2014-A-060 contains course notes from Yale Law School, 1938-1941.

The Boris I. Bittker Papers were processed as a collaborative effort between Manuscripts and Archives and the Yale Law School to document the careers and accomplishments of Law School faculty and alumni.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two series and two additions: I. Correspondence, 1939-2004, undated. II. Topical Files, 1939-2006, undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are two sets of correspondence. The first set is a series of folders arranged alphabetically by last name of correspondent.

The second set is a copy of numbered correspondence from 1980 to 1997 maintained in chronological order. At the beginning of each folder, there is a handwritten index indicating the name of each correspondent and the page number(s) for copies of letters to that individual. For example, the handwritten list for June 1980 to February 1981 indicates that letters to "Adams" will be found on pages 139, 155, and 195. There is no index for the period between July 1996 and November 1997.
Items outside the specified dates may appear in the folders. Researchers should check each folder for complete accuracy.

did.unittitle: American Civil Liberties Union-American College of Tax Counsel
American Association of University Professors (AAUP)-Arkansas Act 10 Litigation Fund (AALS)
Coker, Francis W. Jr. and Kathie
Commissioner v. Clay B. Brown (Clay Brown)
Rothman & Co., Fred B. (Collected Legal Essays)
Yale Law School Class of 1941 Reunion Committee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence, memorandums, newspaper clippings, publications, and other written materials from professional organizations that Boris I. Bittker was employed by, or subject files that he created. Arranged alphabetically by topic or organization name.

Bittker's participation in the prosecution of German saboteurs during World War II is documented in the folders titled Ex Parte Quirin and Office of Lend-Lease Administration. Bittker's interest in race relations and civil rights are shown in his mid-1960s research on black reparations and his 'Black Lawyer' seminar at Yale Law School.

did.unittitle: U. S. v. Jackson, et. al. (Smith Act case)

unittitle.emph: The Yale Survey of Current Legal Issues

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consists of correspondence, notes, and drafts of several unpublished manuscripts by Bittker.

"The Transmission of Wealth from Generation to Generation..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten course notes of law courses taken by Bittker, with some Law School examinations (associated with the notes), and "canned briefs" of notes sold by law students.
